column2: “Neither Mr. Clifton nor your daughter are on that flight
column4: and the boarding desk has already closed. Do you want me to check the 18:50 flight?”|Cometh the Hour|Jeffrey Archer

column2: Lacey stood in the atrium dressed in shorts
column5: ready for a warm evening of walking about. She stared at the tiny red tree frog crouched on a branch at eye level as tour groups and a never-ending stream of smaller parties trooped around her
column6: all wandering the portions of the zig that Swain had opened to the public for the weekend's open house.|The Enclave|Karen Hancock

column1: 18:50|At ten minutes to seven Dulcie was ready. She looked at herself in the wrinkly mirror. The reflection was satisfactory. The dark blue dress
column3: the hat with its jaunty black feather
column4: the but-slightly-soiled gloves--all representing self- denial
column5: even of food itself--were vastly becoming. Dulcie forgot everything else for a moment except that she was beautiful
column6: and that life was about to lift a corner of its mysterious veil for her to observe its wonders. No gentleman had ever asked her out before. Now she was going for a brief moment into the glitter and exalted show.|The Four Million|O. Henry

column1: 18:50|It was time to go see the Lady. When we arrived at her house at ten minutes before seven o'clock
column2: Damaronde answered the door.|Boy's Life|Robert R. McCammon
